awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Stars from Clouds - Turbulence, Magnetic Fields and Dynamics of Forming Star Clusters
awd_abstract_narration:
Stars are formed in molecular clouds of gas in galaxies.   Astronomers seek to understand what causes a particular region of a molecular cloud to form a star. This seemingly simple question is at the heart of several basic research frontiers of modern astrophysics, including galaxy formation and the origin of stellar clusters.  The investigators plan numerical simulations of magnetized molecular clouds that include important physical processes and a variety of initial conditions. The investigators will compare their models to radio wavelength observations of Giant Molecular Clouds (GMCs) from NSF’s Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array (ALMA).  In their studies of the structure and kinematics of GMCs, they will focus on long, filamentary clouds that have been found in the Galactic plane.  The investigators will test models of dynamics of young stellar systems using data from ongoing optical surveys of thousands of young stars. The investigators will train undergraduate and graduate students in advanced research methods, which will be of general benefit in their future careers in either science or industry.  The investigators plan a new “Stars from the Clouds” presentation for public outreach programs.

The team plans numerical simulations of the dynamics of magnetized molecular clouds, including clouds extracted from larger scale shearing galactic disk simulations, giant molecular cloud collisions and idealized periodic box turbulence. A focus of the simulations is inclusion of non-ideal magneto-hydrodynamic processes of ambipolar and reconnection diffusion in adaptive mesh refinement simulations, which also model astrochemistry and predict metrics to be compared to observations. For the stellar cores, the priority will be study of spatial distributions and populations of pre-stellar and proto-stellar cores.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Using advanced computer simulations, the research team, including graduate and undergraduate resaerchers,  has uncovered new insights into how gas in space gathers and collapses to form stars in regions known as "star-forming clouds."  The project focused on understanding how the gas in these star-forming regions behaves under the influence of different forces like gravity, magnetic fields, and feedback from newly formed stars. The team used magnetohydrodynamical (MHD) simulations—complex computer programs that model how gases behave when they are influenced by both magnetic fields and fluid dynamics.

One major result was that the gas in these star-forming regions does not follow a simple pattern. When gravity pulls the gas together, it forms dense clumps that are different from the surrounding area. . They found that the density distribution shows different behaviors depending on whether turbulence or gravity is at play, with gravity causing a power-law shape in dense regions, an indicator of star formation. The simulations showed that gas moves from a "turbulent" state (where it’s held up by random motion) into a state where gravity dominates, causing it to collapse and form stars. This transition happens at a steady rate, and stars form as gas moves from one region of the gas cloud to another. Magnetic fields and the jets of energy shot out by young stars (known as "protostellar feedback") slow down the rate at which gas forms stars. This finding helps explain why star formation doesn’t happen as quickly as you might expect based on the amount of gas present. The researchers also developed new techniques for analyzing how gas behaves in these star-forming clouds. They created a new module for the Torch simulation framework, which adds the ability to simulate the effects of protostellar jets. This is important because these jets can push gas around, affecting how new stars are formed.

This research helps scientists understand how stars like our Sun are formed. By studying star formation, we gain insight into the history of our galaxy and the universe as a whole. It also helps explain why we see stars forming at different rates in different regions of space.
